Baire category theorem

Let {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ be a sequence of continuous real-valued functions on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] and suppose fn(x)f_n\p{x}fn​(x) converges to another real-valued function f(x)f\p{x}f(x) at every x∈[0,1]x \in \br{0, 1}x∈[0,1].

  1. Prove that for every ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 there is a dense subset Dε⊆[0,1]D_\epsilon \subseteq \br{0, 1}Dε​⊆[0,1] such that if x∈Dεx \in D_\epsilonx∈Dε​, then there are an open interval I∋xI \ni xI∋x and a positive integer NxN_xNx​ such that for all n>Nxn > N_xn>Nx​,

    sup⁡y∈I ∣fn(y)−f(y)∣≤ε.\sup_{y \in I}\,\abs{f_n\p{y} - f\p{y}} \leq \epsilon.y∈Isup​∣fn​(y)−f(y)∣≤ε.

    Hint: Consider the closed sets

    FN,ε={y∈[0,1]∣∣fn(y)−fm(y)∣≤ε, ∀n,m>N}.F_{N,\epsilon} = \set{y \in \br{0,1} \mid \abs{f_n\p{y} - f_m\p{y}} \leq \epsilon,\ \forall n, m > N}.FN,ε​={y∈[0,1]∣∣fn​(y)−fm​(y)∣≤ε, ∀n,m>N}.

  2. Prove that fff cannot be the characteristic function χQ∩[0,1]\chi_{\Q\cap\br{0,1}}χQ∩[0,1]​ where Q\QQ is the rational numbers.
Solution.

  1. Observe that

    ⋃N=1∞FN,ε=⋃N=1∞⋂n,m≥N{y∈[0,1]∣∣fn(y)−fm(y)∣≤ε}=[0,1],\bigcup_{N=1}^\infty F_{N,\epsilon} = \bigcup_{N=1}^\infty \bigcap_{n,m \geq N} \set{y \in \br{0,1} \mid \abs{f_n\p{y} - f_m\p{y}} \leq \epsilon} = \br{0, 1},N=1⋃∞​FN,ε​=N=1⋃∞​n,m≥N⋂​{y∈[0,1]∣∣fn​(y)−fm​(y)∣≤ε}=[0,1],

    since fnf_nfn​ converges everywhere to fff. Notice also that because each fnf_nfn​ is continuous, we see that FN,εF_{N,\epsilon}FN,ε​ is an intersection of closed sets, hence closed.

    For any [a,b]⊆[0,1]\br{a, b} \subseteq \br{0, 1}[a,b]⊆[0,1], we see that

    [a,b]=⋃N=1∞FN,ε∩[a,b],\br{a, b} = \bigcup_{N=1}^\infty F_{N,\epsilon} \cap \br{a, b},[a,b]=N=1⋃∞​FN,ε​∩[a,b],

    but [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] is complete and each set in the union is closed, so by the Baire category theorem, FN,ε∩[a,b]F_{N,\epsilon} \cap \br{a, b}FN,ε​∩[a,b] contains an open interval Ia,bI_{a,b}Ia,b​. Let

    Dε=⋃a,b∈[0,1]Ia,b.D_\epsilon = \bigcup_{a, b \in \br{0,1}} I_{a,b}.Dε​=a,b∈[0,1]⋃​Ia,b​.

    We claim that DεD_\epsilonDε​ is dense: if this were not the case, then there exists [a,b]⊆[0,1]\br{a, b} \subseteq \br{0, 1}[a,b]⊆[0,1] such that [a,b]∩Dε=∅\br{a, b} \cap D_\epsilon = \emptyset[a,b]∩Dε​=∅. But Ia,b⊆DεI_{a,b} \subseteq D_\epsilonIa,b​⊆Dε​ by construction, and Ia,b⊆[a,b]I_{a,b} \subseteq \br{a, b}Ia,b​⊆[a,b] as well, so this is impossible, and so DεD_\epsilonDε​ is dense. Finally, given any x∈Dεx \in D_\epsilonx∈Dε​, there exists Ia,b⊆FNx,εI_{a,b} \subseteq F_{N_x,\epsilon}Ia,b​⊆FNx​,ε​ for some Nx∈NN_x \in \NNx​∈N, and if n,m>Nxn, m > N_xn,m>Nx​, we have

    Ia,b⊆Fn,ε  ⟹  sup⁡y∈Ia,b ∣fn(y)−fm(y)∣≤ε.I_{a,b} \subseteq F_{n,\epsilon} \implies \sup_{y \in I_{a,b}} \,\abs{f_n\p{y} - f_m\p{y}} \leq \epsilon.Ia,b​⊆Fn,ε​⟹y∈Ia,b​sup​∣fn​(y)−fm​(y)∣≤ε.

    Sending m→∞m \to \inftym→∞, we get the claim.

  2. If fff were such a function, then by (1), there exists a dense subset D1/4⊆[0,1]D_{1/4} \subseteq \br{0, 1}D1/4​⊆[0,1] with the stated properties. Then for any x∈D1/4x \in D_{1/4}x∈D1/4​, we get I∋xI \ni xI∋x and NxN_xNx​ so that if n>Nxn > N_xn>Nx​, then

    sup⁡y∈I ∣fn(y)−χQ∩[0,1](y)∣≤14.\sup_{y \in I} \,\abs{f_n\p{y} - \chi_{\Q\cap\br{0,1}}\p{y}} \leq \frac{1}{4}.y∈Isup​∣∣​fn​(y)−χQ∩[0,1]​(y)∣∣​≤41​.

    For any q∈Q∩Iq \in \Q \cap Iq∈Q∩I and r∈(R∖Q)∩Ir \in \p{\R \setminus \Q} \cap Ir∈(R∖Q)∩I, we get

    ∣fn(q)−1∣=∣fn(q)−χQ∩[0,1](q)∣≤14.∣fn(r)−0∣=∣fn(r)−χQ∩[0,1](r)∣≤14.\begin{gathered} \abs{f_n\p{q} - 1} = \abs{f_n\p{q} - \chi_{\Q\cap\br{0,1}}\p{q}} \leq \frac{1}{4}\phantom{.} \\ \abs{f_n\p{r} - 0} = \abs{f_n\p{r} - \chi_{\Q\cap\br{0,1}}\p{r}} \leq \frac{1}{4}. \end{gathered}∣fn​(q)−1∣=∣∣​fn​(q)−χQ∩[0,1]​(q)∣∣​≤41​.∣fn​(r)−0∣=∣∣​fn​(r)−χQ∩[0,1]​(r)∣∣​≤41​.​

    But by density, we may send q→rq \to rq→r and apply continuity to get

    ∣fn(r)−1∣≤14,\abs{f_n\p{r} - 1} \leq \frac{1}{4},∣fn​(r)−1∣≤41​,

    which is impossible, since this implies 1≤∣fn(r)−1∣+∣fn(r)−0∣≤121 \leq \abs{f_n\p{r} - 1} + \abs{f_n\p{r} - 0} \leq \frac{1}{2}1≤∣fn​(r)−1∣+∣fn​(r)−0∣≤21​. Thus, χQ∩[0,1]\chi_{\Q\cap\br{0,1}}χQ∩[0,1]​ cannot be the limit of a sequence of continuous functions.
